{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3485450,"name":"","username":"Showblown","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/b4bc9f/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-01-17T05:27:55.363Z","cooked":"

Hello all, I have recently been looking to using NEO/NEO 550s for a personal project. However, as Roborios are fairly expensive, i’d like to use a raspberry pi/arduino. I know you can use PWM with NEOs, but I need to know the encoder value, as well as other things that use a CAN BUS. Unlike CTRE, REVlib doesn’t have any steps for installing it on Non-FRC related boards. I was wondering if anybody had a solution? Thanks

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2025-01-17T05:27:55.363Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":97,"reads":117,"readers_count":116,"score":508.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":482248,"topic_slug":"using-a-neo-and-spark-max-with-raspberry-pi","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":65011,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programming Lead - 3189 Circuit Breakers"},"post_url":"/t/using-a-neo-and-spark-max-with-raspberry-pi/482248/1","custom_user_title":"Programming Lead - 3189 Circuit Breakers","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3485474,"name":"Ada T","username":"cmdada","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cmdada/{size}/230870_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-17T07:12:36.513Z","cooked":"

Unless you somehow get the old spark max server running, you will probably need to interface the encoder directly with the pi and use pwm input for the encoder and pwm output to the motor controller

No idea if this would work in practice, but you could try looking into exactly how the RIO talks to the Spark MAX over PWM, and then replicate that using a Arduino PWM port. Who knows, maybe there is already a library for this.

You would then need to use a third party encoder if you wanted any position control

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2025-01-17T20:32:41.046Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":54,"readers_count":53,"score":15.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":482248,"topic_slug":"using-a-neo-and-spark-max-with-raspberry-pi","display_username":"James Lyon","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":71354,"username":"Lyinlyon","name":"James Lyon","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/lyinlyon/{size}/244534_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":71354,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"8410 Mechanical Lead "},"post_url":"/t/using-a-neo-and-spark-max-with-raspberry-pi/482248/4","custom_user_title":"8410 Mechanical Lead ","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3485987,"name":"Dan","username":"tekdemo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tekdemo/{size}/138330_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-17T20:47:08.678Z","cooked":"

This is, technically, possible. There’s a few things you’d need to do though, as you’d effectively need to replicate the CAN protocol that the Sparks obey.

Step one would be to generate correctly designed CAN packets to the FRC standard. This is fortunately rather well documented here:

FIRST Robotics Competition Documentation

FRC CAN Device Specifications

This document seeks to describe the basic functions of the current FRC ® CAN system and the requirements for any new CAN devices seeking to work with the system. Addressing: FRC CAN nodes assign ar...

Notably, as part of this you would also need to emit RoboRio heartbeat packets; Without these, the spark realizes it’s not on a FRC robot network, and will halt operation. Since this is a safety feature, discussion of exact details to circumvent it is something of a taboo on this forum.

Lastly, tricky part: You have to replicate the CAN frames needed to interface with the spark. The Status Frame API (check the 2024 docs) might help lead you to what is being sent across the wire, since it discusses the particular data and the packet type, and help you read controller outputs.
For the control packets, it’s a bit less clear just from API details, and likely requires more reverse engineering of code and can packets. Rev hasn’t provided public details here, although you’re not the first person to look into it.

There’s some prior work and discussion here that might help. I think the general gist is “contact rev and ask for some documentation”. How can I interface the Spark max Driver with CAN network? - #9 by bebement

Spark maxes use regular rcpwm, literally any arduino that can control a servo can run a spark max over pwm
